title: Analysis of spatial patterns in buildings (access analysis) as an insight into social structure: examples from the Scottish Atlantic Iron Age

references.title: Archaeological Review from Cambridge 5(2): Creating space.
references.raw: BOAST, R.  &  E.  YIANNOULI  (ed.). 1986. Archaeological Review from Cambridge 5(2): Creating space.

references.title: Excavations at Crosskirk broch, Caithness. Edinburgh: Society of Antiquaries of Scotland.
references.raw: FAIRHURST,  H.  1984. Excavations  at Crosskirk  broch, Caithness.  Edinburgh:  Society  of  Antiquaries  of Scotland.

references.title: Fields of Discourse: reconstituting a social archaeology,
references.raw: BARRETT,  J.C. 1988. Fields of Discourse: reconstituting a social  archaeology, Critique  of  Anthropology  7:3 (1987-8):  5-16. Forthcoming. Food, gender  and metal: questions of social  reproduction,  in  M.-L.  Stig-Serensen  &  R Thomas (ed.), The transition from bronze to iron. Oxford: British Archaeological Reports.

references.title: Folk housing in middle Virginia: a structural analysis of historic artefacts.
references.raw: GLASSIE,  H.  1975. Folk  housing  in middle Virginia:  a structural analysis of  historic artefacts. University of Tennessee Press. GRAVES,  C.P. Forthcoming. Social space in the English medieval parish church. approach  is  one which  can  be  adapted  and modified  for  archaeological  purposes.  Social inferences  can  be  derived  from  the  spatial order  by  circumspect  consideration  of  the assumptions behind every appropriate step of the technique, and a clear understanding of the relationship  between  material  culture  and social reproduction. All discourse has a spatial element; access  analysis  is  a  useful  tool  for articulating an understanding of  the part space plays  in structuring  social  relations, and the part social relations have in structuring space.

references.title: Interim report on the structures at Howe, Stromness,
references.raw: CARTER,  S.P., D.  HAIGH,  N.R.J. NEIL  &  B. SMITH.  1984. Interim report on the structures at Howe, Stromness, Orkney, Glasgow Archaeological Journal 11: 61-73.

references.title: Review of Hillier &
references.raw: BATTY,  M.  1985. Review  of  Hillier  &  Hanson  (19841, Sociology 19: 161-2.

references.title: Settlement studies (micro and semimicro],
references.raw: FLETCHER,  R. 1977. Settlement studies (micro and semimicro], in D.L. Clarke  (ed.), Spatial archaeology: 47-162.  London: Academic Press.

references.title: The broch of Mid Howe, Rousay, Orkney,
references.raw: CALLANDER,  J.G.,  & W.G. GRANT.  1934. The broch of Mid Howe, Rousay, Orkney, Proceedings of the Society of Antiquaries of  Scotland 68 (19334):  444-516.

references.title: The constitution of society.
references.raw: GIDDENS,  A. 1984. The constitution of  society. Oxford: Polity Press.

references.title: The division of labour in society.
references.raw: DURKHEIM,  E. 1984. The division  of  labour in society. London: Macmillan.

references.title: The spatial archaeology of gender: a case study of medieval English nunneries, Archaeological Review from Cambridge
references.raw: GILCHRIST,  R. 1988. The spatial archaeology of gender: a case study of medieval English nunneries, Archaeological Review from Cambridge 7(1): 21-8.

references.title: The transformation of space: two examples from British prehistory,
references.raw: BOAST, R. & C. EVANS.  1986 The transformation of space: two examples from British prehistory, in Boast  & Yiannouli (1986):  193-205.

abstract: Clearly the pattern of space in buildings can be expected to relate to the way that buildings are used to structure and reproduce social relations. As an archaeologist, wishing to infer social structure by its reflection in the building pattern, one may hope the relation may be reasonably direct. Here the formal geometrical method of spatial analysis is used to elucidate the pattern in a distinctive kind of prehistoric settlement form, and thence to elucidate the social structure which both produced it and was structured by it
